lots of free education material
easy to find knowlegable people in all tech topics

flashy on the outside, rotting from the core on the inside

solution maintenance and ownership neglected as people move on constantly, so no know how is preserved.

Absolutely zero feedback or reasoning on why people are moved, demoted, ditched from projects.

review_title: Good experience for resume building, no growth potential, low pay
job_title: Datacenter Technician in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
+ Good place to learn datacenter infrastructure for those without much practical work experience
+ This would be a good resume builder for a recent graduate or young professional. I'd say its a job with the training wheels still on
cons:
The datacenter I worked has had a turnover rate of about one person per month for over a year due to the issues below:
- Less than competitive pay without growth opportunity
 - Senior techs passed up for management promotions in favor of outside hires (I saw this happen three times)
 - Low level management located on west coast passed up for west coast regional management promotion (This promotion was given to a manager located in Dallas TWICE)
- Other large companies WILL pay higher hourly wages (FB, Amazon, Microsoft)
- I hadn't received a wage increase my last two years of employment. When I left for another company I doubled my income on base salary alone
- Upper management puts absolutely no trust in its skill proven, senior technicians. Sr techs are given the same amount of trust as a new hire when working on a trouble ticket
- Switched to contract/temp agency employment model

job_title: Digital Product Strategist in Austin, TX
pros:
The gentle tech giant is undergoing a transformation and I have a front seat. I get to work alongside brilliant trailblazers in AI and quantum computing who also happen to be kind, humble.

There are many challenges in the road ahead, so that means a lot opportunities for self-driven, outcome-focused individuals. If you're the kind of person that makes things happen, your work will be swiftly recognized independent of tenure. I've been here three months and I'm getting a promotion next month. Yes, I put in the work, but never expected to see it pay off so quickly.

We work in tech, but life and business are about people and making the world a better place, and there isn't another team or another company that is more committed or has a better track record of doing that than IBM. Being here I understand why people don't leave IBM. Working alongside humans that care about doing the right thing is a fantastic motivator.
cons:
Problems that come from being a huge corporation: bureaucracy, siloed work, status quo inertia.

pros:
If you're in GBS(currently called IBM consulting), you would had chance to work with different clients in different places ( as we're mostly on-site).
That was kind of experiences that most people can never had if they're not in a on-site nature. It always makes you feel fresh to meet a new client and its place.
cons:
Way too much. Illegal & serious overtime working. Working 60hr+ normally, sometimes even ~80hr.
No much useful trainings for young developers. Most campus-hired trainings are about consulting, communication, project management, while most technical IT trainings are only for IT Architects.
Lost of political issues. Promotion is not an objective process. Different service lines differ a lot, and even exp-hired is usually slower than campus-hired significantly.
Bad working environment sometimes when being on-site, ex: meeting room without a window, obsolete office in the basement.

job_title: Director, Developer Relations in Dallas, TX
pros: IBM does have some pros. The sheer size and history are incredible. A lot of diversity, and a lot of insanely smart people
cons:
The cons list is too long to be listed cleanly so I'll try to summarize:
IBM still uses layoffs in a way that (to me) is antiquated.
A lot of long term people's only skill is surviving at IBM.
Expenses and audits are extremely painful. People work in fear of getting a resource action or an audit.
Extremely talented people get resourced just because the machine is too big to really notice them.

job_title: Major Incident Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: IBM offers many training programs and there is a lot of different opportunities to explore.
cons:
Performance base raises and bonuses are not a thing at IBM. You have to advance your career to gain any financial advancement. Not a bad thing for most, but you need to know this going in.

IBM is not the kind of company that puts anything above profits. They will dump a project quickly (along with all its employees) if they do not see a substantial financial return. If you are a person that thinks that a publicly traded company should emphasis doing good at the cost of the dollar, this is not your place. (Search Watson or any of the groundbreaking medical things they have done in the past for context)

It really matters where you work (what project) at IBM. If you are not in a profitable department, you should start looking to either find and get into one that is or leave IBM.

review_title: IBM Consulting / GBS : Experience will be solely based on team and manager
pros: All the good thing that comes with 100 years old company. HR practices are not optimal. There are some good service-based opportunities in IBM.
cons:
Specific to IBM GBS / Consulting:

It is true as mentioned by many reviews that IBM experiences are different for each team because there are no good integrity practices followed by managers and leads. IBM says that the manager is the first point of contact for any hr related queries even it is hard to contact HR. This is like asking prisoners to guard the prison gate. How can you confront the manager that your likable is not working with full integrity? What managers will do is that they select a few individual as an unofficial lead and now you have to dance to whatever tune they play. You even cannot raise the question against them. They will decide what story you work on and how many points will be assigned to this story. You have become puppets and dance to their rhythm. Forget about changing the project as your manager will not easily let you go and hr is just a name. If you are likable by the team then it will be a great time for you.
3 points are given for IBM name only not for GBS.

job_title: Enablement Program Manager in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: First what keeps me at IBM is the people, no matter what's going on, the people who work with you matter and I've always had amazing people guiding and supporting me. Another key aspect from a practical perspective really is the flexibility, not only in your daily work, but the flexibility to move to new roles and experiment new ways of doing things. Lastly it's just amazing the access we have to so many learning resources. I've learned so many new skills, both soft and technical. They've all contributed to building my career and allowed me to grow.
cons: The best thing about IBM is also the worst thing about IBM, it's big, it's huge. This means that there are many careers to chose from and possibilities to completely reinvent yourself, but it means it's also hard to navigate at times. With so many options sometimes it's hard to know what to do. It's also a challenge to stand out beyond your immediate team or organization. It also means that organizational change takes time, it's a big ship, it doesn't turn fast.

review_title: LOVE working at IBM and the growth potential
pros: Since joining IBM in 2019, I have learned so much and seen such continued opportunities for growth and advancement that I'm continuously inspired to learn as much as possible! I've transitioned from operations support to a hybrid business management team and cannot express how much I've loved witnessing the growth, unite together to figure it out attitude and uncapped potential to aim HUGE that I've seen from my tribe and our expanded teams.
cons: We are a global organization and not everyone has had the great fortune I have with my exceptional manager and leadership team within CIO. They are accessible, they listen and genuinely want to make IBM the best place to work with the highest returns for our shareholders. However, I have found that encouraging my colleagues who are not enjoying their work for whatever reason: management, outgrowing their role, lack of inspiration/ education to reach their next milestone- TRANSITION! An advantage of our huge company is that there are always opportunities to learn and grow. your skills on another team. This cycle of growth is rewarding for all parties involved.

review_title: Flexible, comfortable income, unlimited income potential (but have to be realistic)
job_title: Brand Sales Specialist in Dallas, TX
pros:
- Flexible, my position is 100% remote, no requirement to EVER go into the office (this was the case prior to covid as well)
- Comfortable income
- Theoretically unlimited income potential through commission (but have to be realistic)
- No micromanagement whatsoever, you just have to perform and stay on top of your responsibilities
- Not the best benefits compared to some other companies, but not bad by any means. 401k match, PTO (my manager doesn't even care if I use PTO, just have my backup in place), healthcare benefits
- Company provided Macbook and monitor
- If you don't like your role, you can make it known to your manager and they make it seamless to get you switched to another position you may like more, even if not in the same area. Hypothetical example... You discover you hate sales and want to switch to working in marketing. They make that very easy whereas some companies it's pretty impossible or extremely difficult to jump to an entire different area
cons:
- Lack of clear direction from the company, constant reorgs and changes
- To the prior point, you cover specific accounts in my role, the top accounts IBM has as customers/clients. So it's heavily based on the relationship you develop with your accounts, but every year you get assigned new accounts taking away that element. This is not good for customers either
- Depending on your portfolio, number of accounts, how much your accounts "like" IBM vs AWS or Microsoft, etc, it could be hard or at least more difficult to make sales.
-

pros:
It is the great place to work. Some of the fantastic minds and interesting projects you will find working here. IBM has some of the world's biggest clients. You will not find the culture anywhere else in TCS, Cognizant or Wipro etc. Off course there are cases as exceptions but mostly Managers are understanding and caring. Work life balance is at its best.

The best way to find the difference is, you work here for more than 5 years and find yourself somewhere else for another 5 years and come back again. You'll start finding the difference in every steps of your daily day life. In my previous tenure I have been to places to support my clients for IBM and my memories are still fresh that how I had been treated with respect from my local physician's chamber to a letting agent or at the airport during immigration.
cons: On the contrary, the major complain off course is a low growth. Mostly are increments less than 10% if it is not a promotion and simple salary hike each year. Finally, IBM is a top brand and if you are here, you will always have an edge.
